awd_titl_txt: Equations of State of Superdense Nuclear Matter for Use in Neutron Star Merger Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
The observation of the first binary neutron star merger named GW170817 using LIGO and VIRGO led the scientific community into the era of multi-messenger astronomy with gravitational waves.  Numerical relativity simulations have shown that the pressure-density relationship (known as equation of state) of hot and dense matter plays a fundamental role in simulating the collisions of neutron stars.  Neutron stars are up to twice as massive as our Sun but are typically only around 20 kilometers across. At such extraordinary densities, atomic nuclei collapse, and neutrons and protons are squeezed so tightly together that they may disintegrate into a plasma made of up and down quarks, which are the most fundamental building blocks of matter.  The goal of this project is to determine a comprehensive set of state-of-the art models for the equation of state of superdense nuclear matter for use by researchers working on neutron-star merger simulations. In particular, the group will investigate the role of quarks for neutron-star mergers and identify possible signals by means of which quarks may register themselves in the gravitational-wave signals produced by merging neutron stars. The models for the equation of state will be made available to the community at online services (CompOSE, StellarCollapse). Graduate and undergraduate students at San Diego State University will be trained in areas of physics which are richly interdisciplinary and enrich their educational experience beyond what they learn in the classroom.

The overarching goal of this project is to determine a comprehensive set of state-of-the art models for the equation of state of hot and dense nuclear matter for use by researchers working on neutron-star merger simulations.  Contemporary effective field theoretical models, i.e., the relativistic density-dependent Hartree (DDRMF) model and the (local and the non-local) 3-flavor Polyakov-Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (3PNJL) model, will be used to accomplish this goal. The DDRMF is a versatile and numerically tractable nuclear many-body theory well suited for studies of dense and dense hadronic matter. The 3PNJL model is an effective model of quantum chromodynamics which allows for a contemporary modeling of quark matter. It provides a functional and numerically tractable approach to quantum chromodynamics. The model accounts for the dynamical breaking of chiral symmetry and mimics quark confinement via the Polyakov-loop potential. Quark deconfinement at zero and finite temperature will be studied using both the Gibbs and Maxwell condition for phase equilibrium. The strongest, currently possible constraints from nuclear theory, nuclear experiment, and astrophysics will be used to fix the parameters of the effective field theories and test the validity of the equations of state.

This project advances the objectives of "Windows on the Universe: the Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics", one of the 10 Big Ideas for Future NSF Investments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the properties of neutron stars, dense remnants of massive stars, to deepen our understanding of matter under extreme conditions. Neutron stars are unique laboratories of nature, with densities far exceeding those of atomic nuclei and temperatures reaching millions of degrees. These extraordinary conditions make them ideal for studying the behavior of matter under pressures and densities that cannot be replicated on Earth. Their study provides insights into fundamental physics, including the behavior of matter at high densities and the forces that govern it, contributing to our broader understanding of the universe.

 Intellectual Merit

The project developed advanced computational models for the equation of state (EOS) of neutron star matter, which describe how matter behaves under the immense pressures and temperatures found in neutron stars. These models incorporated cutting-edge quantum mechanical theories of many-body systems, which are essential for accurately describing the interactions between particles in such extreme environments. By modeling the intricate balance of forces within neutron stars, the EOS provides a critical link between the dense matter inside these stars and their observable properties, such as mass and radius.

 A key outcome was the creation of EOS models for hot and dense nuclear matter, applicable to phenomena such as proto-neutron stars (newly formed, extremely hot neutron stars) and neutron star mergers. These models accurately describe the behavior of neutron star matter at various temperatures and densities and have been validated against observational data, such as the masses and radii of neutron stars. The findings also provided new insights into the role of exotic particles, like hexaquarks, in shaping neutron star properties. These particles, which are predicted to exist at extremely high densities, may have significant implications for the stability and evolution of the most massive neutron stars.

The project introduced innovative methods, such as using machine learning to infer EOS parameters directly from X-ray telescope spectra. This novel approach allowed the research team to analyze data from telescopes more effectively, linking theoretical models with real-world observations. 

 Broader Impacts

The project significantly impacted education, workforce development, and public understanding of science. Over its duration, students (undergraduates and graduates) received training that extended beyond the standard curriculum. Topics covered included quantum mechanics, computational physics, and relativistic astrophysics, equipping students with specialized skills to tackle complex problems. Through this hands-on training, students gained experience in advanced numerical methods, programming, and data analysis, preparing them for graduate programs and careers in STEM fields. This training emphasized not only technical expertise but also critical thinking and problem-solving skills applicable across a variety of disciplines.

 The educational impact extended further with the publication of the second edition of Introduction to Computational Physics for Undergraduates. This book equips students in STEM sciences with modern computational tools, including Python and Fortran, and interactive Jupyter Notebooks. These tools allow students to visualize and interact with complex data, fostering deeper learning and preparing them for real-world scientific challenges.

 Research results were widely disseminated, including over 30 refereed journal articles, a book chapter, and conference proceedings. These publications contributed to the scientific community’s understanding of neutron stars and dense matter. Additionally, the project produced a book titled Astrophysics in the XXI Century with Compact Stars, offering a comprehensive overview of compact star physics for researchers and students. These efforts not only advanced the field but also provided accessible resources for education and collaboration.

 Equation of state datasets have been made publicly available, allowing other researchers to build on this work. Additionally, the numerical codes developed during the project are available upon request to research groups working on proto-neutron stars and neutron star merger simulations. This accessibility ensures that the project’s tools and findings continue to benefit the broader scientific community.

 An important side effort of the project addressed quantum gravity and its implications for gravitational waves and compact objects like neutron stars. Building on the foundational role of gravitational waves in compact star research, additional work investigated how quantum gravity frameworks influence the dynamics of spacetime and could explain the generation of relic gravitational waves. These waves, which carry information about the early universe, offer a unique window into fundamental physics and cosmology. 

Conclusion

By addressing fundamental questions about the universe and equipping the next generation of scientists with advanced skills, this project has made a lasting impact on both science and society. The innovative models and methods developed during the project provide new insights into the behavior of matter under extreme conditions, with implications for astrophysics, nuclear physics, and gravitational wave astronomy. At the same time, the educational and collaborative aspects of the project have fostered a new generation of researchers, contributing to a more informed and scientifically capable society. This dual focus on advancing knowledge and building capacity ensures the project’s enduring legacy in both scientific discovery and human development.
